Head Quarters Marshal Liu's Army Chungking May 31,1933
Dear Family
I know that the above address will be something of a surpris
to you but the truth is that we are stranded by bad weather at ab
an air port about twelve miles below Chungking which happens to be
the base of operations of one of the chief war lords of China. The
Marshal is the Governor of Schechuan Province which is located in
the heart of China, more than 1500 miles up the Yangstze River from
the sea. It is the richest and reputed to be the most populous
province in this whole country. We flew up here from Shanghai and
arrived last Sunday with the intention of immediately flying still
farther on to Chengtu, which is the last outpost of civilization
before youbreach Tibet, in fact from Chengtu you can see Tibet.
On reaching Changking we called on the Marshal to pay our respects
and officially notify him that in accordance with permission prev-
iously obtained from him we were about to inaugurate service to
Chengtu. He promptly told us that there was a war going on between
his army and that of his Uncle at Chengtu and that he could not br
responsible for anything that might befall us if we went on without
first getting the permission of the military chief at Chengtu. Wec
were afraid that some fool soldier at Chengtu might take a shot at
us if we started in to land so there was nothing to do but get busy
on the telegraph line and try to fix up everything with the author-
ities at Chengtu before going over there. We were unable to get all
factions straightened out until today (Wednesday) and then the visi-
bility turned out to be zero and as a result here we are at the air-
port waiting for a chance to leave. It is now late and I know that
we will not be able to go on until tomorrow morning. Therefore Bond
operations manager for China National Aviation Corp., Chief Pilot
Allison who is doing the flying on this trip, and our Chinese man-
